content.description:
Sit start and climb the right face of the arete



Behind boulder Malamute at the right of Dreamcatcher's route

SDS matched on a good block with choice of feet. Follow the overhang to the right using ledges and increasingly slopey holds, top out on the arete at the apex of the overhang. Be wary of a block that is coming loose near the bottom of the arete as many people used this hold to move through the crux of the problem. 
  
 From the SDS move left and up the slab for the easier, but drier "Some Beautiful Things Remain"

Coming down the trail from the Gateway and Nine-Tenths areas this problem is located on the right, just off the path (on the backside of the Malaria boulder).
Pad if desired, more importantly to keep your feet dry as this boulder is located at the edge of the swamp.

Start on the left side of the slightly overhanging arete with a pinch for the right hand and a small edge for the left. Climb up the arete staying on the left side. Make use of the right facing corner and most likely a very high step for the right foot. While the crux is likely pulling off the high step the topout is slopey so be prepared to mantel it out. On the Nine-Tenths boulder, on the same face as Bullfighter's Friend. The starting holds for Blackfly are on the right arete while Bullfighter starts to the left.
Downclimb the prominent crack on the trail-facing side of the boulder. A pad should be sufficient, a spotter if the topout bothers you.

Sit start and climb the blunt arete

Départ assis et grimper l'arête.



The arete on the right detached bloc of Gateway

L'arête sur le petit bloc détaché de Gateway

SDS with hands matched on the bottom ledge in the series of "steps". Move up the obvious line trending towards the right. Various beta exists but most includes using the left facing corner and making a stretch to the sloping lip. Once established on the lip throw a heel up and mantle over the top. 
  
 A similar line "Ambassador of Kick-Yer-Assiter" (FA Denny Wong) follows the stepped edges but eliminates the lip, instead moving through the left facing corner and topping out further right.  
  
 Each variation is worth a try, these problems had previously been considered the "benchmark" for v4 in the area, but more recently both have been re-evaluated as V3. Might feel somewhat stiff for a 3 to some, especially if you don't have the reach to simply stick the lip from the blocky steps.

Located on the backside of the Nine-Tenths boulder, the boulder following The Gateway along the trail. Pretty prominent line on a great boulder.
pad and spotter, the landing is decent but try not to flail off the top.

Sit start on a crimp in the small left facing corner and climb up



On the face of West Nile between a small roc close of the pond and the path from Nine-Tenths

Vertical wall. Start on two small crimps slightly right of the middle of the wall. Move up and top out.

On the Marsh boulder, located on the side facing the marsh. There is a log platform preventing you from sinking into the marsh. Getting down you go to the other side of the boulder.
1 or 2 crash pads

Start on a prominent flake with many options for feet. Move straight up through a cluster of holds (including a pinch, crimps, and an undercling) avoiding the good holds further to the right. Aim for the jug directly above this cluster that seems so close, and yet... The first three ascents of this problem were all done in very different styles, so play around with different beta on the various holds until something clicks for you. Surprisingly all versions feel about V5. Since the first few ascents one or two footholds have broken/crumbled making this problem more challenging. I've tried two of the three betas I know of and both were somewhat harder, I'm assuming the undercling beta (used for the FA) is similarly changed. Starts on the prominent flake to the left of Westward Ho! on the West Nile Boulder.
As this problem is on the swamp facing side of the boulder it may be largely inaccessible once the snow melts and the water level rises. A pad or two, the landing is somewhat uneven.

Climb the face anywhere between the off-width crack and the left side of the face.



Boulder Malamute close of the cliff juste at the left of the indication "Mid-Cliff"

SDS with right hand on a low thumbcatch sidepull and left higher up on a sloping edge with bad smeary feet. Make a couple moves up through sloping edges to grab the lip. Make a somewhat difficult and committing mantel to finish.

Located on the backside of the Phobia boulder, to the left of the "pit". Other problems start on a prominent ledge that runs across the boulder, the starting holds for this problem are to the right of this ledge.
pad over the jumbled rock landing

Start on the obvious crimp 6ft right of the arete. Pull on with difficulty and climb the slab to the top.

A sit start is  possible with a lower crimp a few feet to the right and goes about the same grade.



In the middle of the Nine-Tenths boulder on the slab face.

Stand start with a left hand undercling and right hand sidepull on the face (left) side of the arete. Make a move up through a crimp and edges to top out at the top of the arete. The crux seems to be making the first move without your feet popping off the wall. Stay to the left of the arete as the right side is another problem. 
  
 One of a few decent (and easier) problems on the Africa Boulder that isn't height dependent.

Start on the far right hand side of the Africa Boulder.
pad if you like

SDS as for Gateway Arete and move up the arete to gain the obvious sloping ledge which traverses right along the length of the boulder. Various options and contrivances exist but for the V1 version continue along this edge until it ends at the right-facing corner. Climb up using edges to an easy mantel. 
  
 Another option is to traverse the edge to about midway on the boulder and fire up to the lip linking into Put All Your Fears To Rest. This involves a satisfying dyno move and a slightly more challenging mantel.

On the trail facing side of the Gateway Boulder.
pad if you like

SDS on a left hand pinch and right hand edge. Move directly up through sloping edges, crux seems to be sticking a small slot/crimp. Good movement on a slightly overhanging boulder makes for a nice warmup.

Located on the left hand side of the first boulder encountered (the gateway boulder) if you take the new trail below the cliff and talus.
pad if you like, the landing is good and the problem not very high

SDS on the large incut ledge under the short roof. Using sloping holds go direct over the lip and up the crack to a top out jug. Careful footwork makes this go fairly easily.

The first boulder encountered when following the main path below the talus and alongside the swamp. Found to the left of the trail just before heading up the slight rise that goes to the Gateway Boulder. The start hold is located under the obvious roof.
pad

SDS on the left side of the Gateway Boulder at the base of the arete. Move up large edges, some slightly sloping, to the lip, top out. Decent climbing but very short.

On the far left of the trail facing side of the Gateway Boulder, the first obvious boulder encountered if following the new trail below the cliff and talus.
Pad if desired

Start low to the left of Ken's Super Slab on a low undercling and power out and right to some slopey crimps before topping out on the slab. Pay attention to your feet on the starting moves because it feels much harder if you don't place them correctly. The undercling move is almost all bicep...


Left and underneath of Ken's Super Slab
One pad is fine

SDS on the jug flake under the roof as per November. Move up and left until you hit the sloping lip. Where November uses the huge jug at the lip and then tops out through the blocky corner, High Road traverses left along the lip using slopes, crimps, and powerful heels to top out at the far left side of the boulder. While it might be possible to top out at any point, fight through the forearm pump until you reach edges and jugs to top out on the left side. 
  
 A great problem that feels less contrived than it sounds, the movement is excellent and the length is somewhat unique for Calabogie. An edge about a foot above the lip has been cleaned/dug out fairly recently which may make the problem easier, so if you want to do the original line just avoid this seam. 
  
 This problem traverses along the lip of the boulder, the heavily chalked sloping, diagonal ledge running under the roof is the Low Road V8, which looks excellent but is also harder.

Starts as per November under the roof of the Frigid Cave Boulder, behind and to the left of the Gateway Boulder
a few pads or a spotter to move one in order to cover the blocks resting under the cruxes.

Stand start on good foot holds and move up the slab using a couple crimps, the obvious ledge, and the smooth arete.

On the back of the Gate boulder, the obvious slab.
Pad

Stand start on crimps and/or the blocky arete with choice of slippery feet. Make some moves on perfect (if slightly sharp) crimps for the left hand and slap up the arete with your right. Grap a left facing corner above the lip and top out. Excellent problem which requires some technique. 
  
 Eliminating the arete and beginning on crimps a bit further left (right hand is on the crimp used for the left hand when starting Horde Juggernaut...) is Coordination Tongue (V6)  
  
 This face catches far more sun than any other at Calabogie, making it an ideal spot on cold days, but the crimps get slick quickly in the summer.

Located on the swamp facing side of the Marsh Boulder. From the clearing in the highball area head through the passage to the right of the Apathy Boulder (the scooped slab with a diagonal crack running across the top). The Marsh Boulder is to your right so walk towards the marsh and turn right onto trampled down reeds to find this sun-baked, orange face.
pad, watch the somewhat uneven landing as this boulder is about as close to the marsh as you can get.

Climb arret on the left of the boulder to peak

Route is before new Squamish and after the great roof in the area marked as "Talus Field" in old PDF guide.
none

Located about 40 yards past and just uphill from the Gateway Boulder, this problem is a great "one move wonder" dyno off of small crimps to the lip. The two obvious crimps look better than they feel and you have to use your feet just right to get enough momentum with your left hand to stick the lip.


40 yards past and about 15 yards uphill from the Gateway Boulder.
Couple pads

Stand start by carefully pulling onto the slab. Various beta exists to accomplish this, but common beta (and the style of the FA) uses a high right foot at the lip, high right hand on a sharp sidepull that can also be crimped to some degree, and low left hand against the slab to create some tension.  
 Once your left foot is established, follow the left-trending feature that can be used as a sidepull/undercling for the left hand and gain thin crimps for the right. Technical footwork will bring you to the top of a great slab.

Located on the far right of the Nine-tenths boulder on the opposite side of Bullfighter's Friend. If you are following the trail from The Gateway the slab will be almost facing you as you approach Nine-Tenths.
pad, landing is decent

Stand start on thin but obvious crimps on the right side of the highball boulder. Follow the line of crimps direct, making a series of long movements to gain rounded holds, finishing with a somewhat highball mantel. Creative use of a prominent crimp flake, and more importantly technical footwork will bring success! Treat the prominent crimp flake (gained with the first move after pulling on) with care, it flexes noticeably on its underside. I thought this was an excellent technical crimp line, only two stars because of the flexing crimp. Located on the right hand side of the Highball boulder, with the starting crimps a few feet right of Waiting in Line for the Electric Chair.
As with the other problems on this boulder the downclimb is a bit tricky. pad(s) and a spotter
This problem is not as high as Electric Chair but is fairly sustained near the top and has an angled landing.
The spotter will especially come in handy if the flexing hold decides to snap off.

SDS (carefully) on a finger-jug under the short roof. Using heel and toe trickery to keep body tension move low and right through a series of decent edges. Once established on the highest good edge either move up and slightly right to an interesting crimp/pinch hold before locking off to the lip, or just dyno it out. Really nice movement on this one and the presence of tepid bog-water under the beginning moves adds a bit of spice to this otherwise ass-dragging problem. If you would rather not risk a soaker, start standing on the good edge and finish with the pinch move or the dyno. This is "Rescue" and goes at about V1. On the swamp facing side of the West Nile Boulder. Head around the boulder until you find a V shaped indent in the boulder that forms a small overhang on either side. The starting hold for Lost at Sea can be found under the right hand side overhang.

This problem is only really accessible in the early spring before the snow and ice melts, raising the water level of the swamp. Pad and maybe a tarp depending on the water level.

Start low under a small cave with right hand at the lip (low start is V5). Once you hit the rail you have to match and move out left for the pumpy and awkward lip traverse for which there is multiple beta. Some people try to heel hook and work their way out the lip before the awkward mantle. I campused through this section as my heel felt insecure but either way its hard. 
  
 We need some pics of this....

Near the pond, obvious roof problem starting low.
Make sure you get a pad low to protect your back from the sharp slab on the opening move.

Low start to Malaria. 
  
 Start low under a small cave below the high start to Malaria. Get your left heel on or just flag it and use a far right foot well underneath to do the lock off move to the lip. Now finish Malaria. 
  
 First move is a bit of a backscratcher with a rock close behind your back. Be careful.

Couple pads - one down low because there is a rock behind you that wants to gouge your back.

Sit start in the short left facing corner. Climb up to the lip and the easy mantle.

Départ assis dans le coin. Grimper sur la bordure et rétablir sur le haut du bloc.



Dans le petit coin sur la droite du bloc Gateway

Sit start 5 feet left of Manteling 101. Climb up the well featured face then a mantle.

Départ assis 5 pieds à côté de Manteling 101. Grimper droit sur la face avec plusieurs bonnes prises et se rétablir sur la vire.



Between Put All Your Fears to Rest and Manteling 101

Entre Put All Your Fears to Rest et Manteling 101

SDS matched on an obvious flake with decent feet. November moves to the left following the rail feature and incorporating a sharp crimp for the left hand and a potentially painful heel hook. From here a big move will take you to a huge jug at the lip. The topout was cleaned off this past fall, adding some enjoyable moves to get established above the lip.

Located under the small roof on the boulder behind and to the left of the Gateway boulder.
A pad and/or a spotter to protect a rock and tree which can become dangers if you swing off or miss the big jug.

Stand start matched on a flake just under the lip with your choice of a number of slippery edges for feet. Make a few moves up through right facing incut crimps in order to slap to the blunt arete which runs up the centre of the boulder. Finish up the arete as per Orbital Traverse. A number of options exist to move through the crimps to the arete all of which are somewhat awkward. It might also be possible to sit start this problem by moving up through the sloping edges that are eventually used for feet. This would be considerably harder than the stand. Starts just under the lip to the right of the blunt arete in the middle of the Orbital Boulder. The Orbital Traverse begins on the far left hand side of this boulder and moves up through blocky corners to the arete. From the arete look down and to the right, the starting flake should be fairly obvious.

The Orbital Boulder is located just to the right of the Tigerlily Boulder, near the end of the main approach trail. From the Highball/Malaria area follow the trail through some jumbled boulders (The Slab and Africa Boulders are found here) for a few minutes. The Tigerlily Boulder is tall and has a prominent ledge running through it. pad

SDS at the lowest point of the left end of the boulder (closest to the Tigerlily Boulder), follow the series of rising, blocky corners until the blunt, sloping arete around the centre. Make moves to edges higher up and roll over the lip, finishing up the low angle slab. The traverse right can be somewhat pumpy if you move slowly with the crux coming at the move to the edges once the underside of the boulder steepens.

On the shorter boulder next to the Tigerlily Boulder. The Tigerlily Area is the second last area with established problems if you are following the lower trail along the swamp which begins at The Gateway Boulder. Tigerlily is a very  prominent and aesthetic line and Orbital Traverse stands out as well with its blocky corners.
pad for the crux if desired

SDS on left of large crack. Reach up to round nub, traverse right to triangle crimp and gain the upper peak. Avoid arret.

Route is before new Squamish and after the great roof in the area marked as "Talus Field" in old PDF guide.
None

Great line on the backside of the Highball Boulder - start on some high crimps and work your way up a precarious and delicate face. The crux is super cryptic and the feet are horrible at first. I am not going to give away beta here in part because I had to work out the sequence over multiple visits.

; )

Note...

This problem is listed in the online guide as V4. The current consensus (other than the guidebook) is V5/6. I would call it a stout V5+ or V6 (depending on the area). The top moves are not trivial and involve a large dyno with your feet about 10 feet OTD so pad up.


Backside of the highball boulder
Need at least three pads

climbs.name: Put All Your Fears To Rest

content.description:
SDS/Crouch start along the sloping ledge which runs across the Gateway Boulder. Dyno or deadpoint to the lip and mantel.  
  
 This problem can vary greatly in difficulty depending on where you choose to begin, with the most challenging version moving direct through the blankest section of the face about midway along the boulder. As the problem is very short, dynoing this blank section is by far the most satisfying option.

On the Gateway Boulder, about midway along the sloping rail which runs across the boulder.
pad if you like

Climb up the featured face



Between the arete and tree in front of you when you arrived by Gateway path

Stand start on the undercling rail and a very high crimp/pinch around the middle of the boulder. Establish your feet then pull up hard on the crimp/pinch in order to reach an assortment of gaston/crimps that seem to be facing the wrong way. From here find somewhere to smear your feet and make a toss for a ledge at the top of the boulder, top out. 
  
 The starting undercling recently broke, not really changing the difficulty but potentially leaving this problem even more height dependent with the loss of a foothold. If you are under 5'10" this will probably feel harder than v4.

Start around the middle of the Africa Boulder, the (broken) undercling and high crimp/pinch are fairly obvious. The Africa Boulder is found just before the Tigerlily Area if you are following the trail from the Highball area. The boulder is a vertical face with a blank section running through its centre.
pad

Stand start on a crimp and a sloping edge around chest height just right of a tree. Move up and right through decent but somewhat hidden holds with some tricky, slick feet. 
  
 The original and full line starts on the left arete and traverses into the start holds for the direct version. If you can squeeze past the tree this might still go but doesn't add much value or challenge.

On the backside of the Apathy Boulder. The Apathy boulder is opposite the Malaria Boulder and the problem West Nile Direct, it has a scooped face with a decent V0. From the "clearing" walk around on the right or through a tunnel on the left to find the starting holds for this problem in the middle of the boulder.
pad

Stand or SDS, either way the starting holds are sidepulls found along the edges of the prominent bulge feature. While both versions require a wide wingspan, the SDS is more height dependent feeling like v4 while the stand is closer to v3. Squeeze and slap your way upwards using edge sidepulls until high crimps allow for an exit to the right into the depression, or straight up. Heading direct feels less secure and may need a scrub first. Located on the cliff-facing side of the Highball boulder. From "Waiting in Line..." go around the right side of the boulder, this problem is the first you will encounter.

This area is also the common downclimb for the Highball boulder, it is a good idea to get a feel for the problems here before attempting Waiting in Line... At least one pad is nice, a spotter can protect against the uneven landing further back as well.

Left hand start of Electric Chair. Do some hard V4+ moves starting on the left hand side of the boulder that Electric Chair is on. There are some obvious awkward side pulls and poor feet to start. Pull up and into a poor gaston crimp and then cross over your left hand into some bad crimps that are used for the footholds on Electric Chair (V4/5). Now traverse right into Electric Chair, shake out and save some energy for the final left lock-off move on Electric Chair that goes to the lip. Make another move to get to the very top which is a Thank God jug!



Lots of pads. I took the fall up around 15 feet in the iron cross section which was wild but fun. A fall on the final moves of Electric Chair would be sketchy but probably ok (?) with enough pads and good spotters.

This is a really nice line next to the right of Sahara.

Start with two strange underclings and some really awkward splayed feet - one far out left, one on a tiny dimple beneath you. Now pull up into an extremely sharp crimp (the "sword" crimp), get a poor gaston for your right, shuffle your feet a bit and dead point for an obvious pinch crimp up over the lip before slapping the top.

The sequence is very aesthetic. A contender for the best V6 in the area.


Just before you get to Tiger Lily and Orbital Traverse
Couple pads tops. I used an extra pad wrapped around the tree behind the problem as you can fall into it.

Start with an undercling and your right foot heel hooked on the rail near the start of Gatineau Special. You can get a heel-toe cam thing going. Now do the big left hand move to the crimp at the start of Twisted. 

Option 1: Match the obvious left hand crimp and finish Twisted as usual (*hard).

Option  2: Right hand to the side pull crimp. Heel hook your left foot onto the rail near the start of Twisted and bump your left hand hard to the good sloper hold at the lip and finish as per Twisted.




Sit down start to Twisted by Design.
Couple pads is fine

Sit down start, start climbing the left facing dihedral and continue up to top out. There are branches you have to crawl under at the top out. 
  
  youtube.com/watch?v=CCJa-eb…

The boulder is located at the back of the Calabogie bouldering area. There is a swamp nearyby. You can get down the boulder at the back.
Bring crashpads

Stand start matched on a good undercling rail with your choice of solid feet. A big move, likely a dyno unless you are particularly tall, leads roughly straight up to an angled, arrow-shaped rail. Match, and head straight up to the lip, this time relying on your rubber for footing. 
  
 V4 in the guide, but this grade is "severely height dependent".

Located on the Africa Boulder, found along the trail just before the Tigerlily Boulder if you are coming from the Highball area. The boulder is a fairly obvious vertical face with a blank mid section. Trade Route... starts a few feet in from the left arete, wherever the undercling feels best to you.
pad

SDS on the same good flake as "November". Instead of moving to the left up the rail make a stab out right to a small, sharp crimp. As for November the crux comes reaching for a big jug at the lip of the boulder. Once you stick the (rightmost) jug, pull the lip and top out directly up the slab using small crimps and some mantel powers.

Located under the small roof on the boulder behind and to the left of the Gateway Boulder.
Same as November, pad and/or spotter to watch for a swing backwards into rocks and a tree.

SDS matched on an obvious crimp just under the lip of a small overhang with a number of options for feet. Make a hard pull over the lip to a uneven ledge, then a series of awkward, bunched cross moves to get established on the arete. Short and tough. 
  
 A harder extension begins under the overhang to the right on a hidden undercling and traverses into the starting crimp. This is The Theorem V7.

This problem is located on the trail facing arete on the Nine-Tenths boulder. If you are following the trail from the Gateway boulder this is the first problem encountered. The start hold is well chalked for Calabogie and obvious.
pad for first hard move

climbs.name: Waiting in Line for the Electric Chair

content.description:
Super highball line on the backside of Malaria. This line is tall and starts on an obvious set of crimps on the right hand side of the obvious main face of the tall boulder. Beware though as the crux comes at the very end about 17-18 feet OTD - big lock off move. Once you hit the lip with your left hand before to adjust your feet and move again right to the top which is a huge jug...

Several pads and several spotters

Stand start on the lowest point of the prominent ledge which rises up and left into Tigerlily. This eliminates the difficult SDS and opening moves of Tigerlily but retains a big move off the ledge to a sidepull jug and the delicate finishing moves on somewhat hidden edges.  
  
 The topout may require some cleaning and care around the branches from a nearby tree. The downclimb should also be done with care as the backside of the boulder is covered in debris and a lot of moss.

On the Tigerlily Boulder, the second last area with established problems if following the trail from the Gateway Boulder along the swamp. The starting ledge is obvious.
Pads for the uneven, rocky landing, and a spotter would help confidence as you move off of the juggy rail to smaller holds.

climbs.name: West Nile Direct
climbs.fa: Jody Miall (the full West Nile line)

content.description:
Direct start to the longer West Nile V7ish. SDS matched on a sloping edge underneath the roof. Some start with feet deeper under the short roof, but a more interesting beta involves facing feet outwards and lifting off the ground using a toe hook on a triangular ledge at the lip. Bring hands to feet and continue upwards along the slopey corner and top out.  
  
 The full line starting at the far right of the roof section near Malaria traverses along ledges to link up with West Nile Direct. The grade is unconfirmed as far as I know, and beta is unclear at this point.

On the far left end of the Malaria Boulder just before the Westward Ho! face. The starting holds (especially the ledge at the lip) should be visible from the clearing which is home to the Highball and Malaria Boulders. Beautiful Odyssey is on the opposite side of this boulder and Malaria is to the right of this problem.
Crash pads under the roof to protect your tailbone from some rock.

Stand start with holds around waist to chest height. Head straight up. The moves get slightly longer as you make your way higher. Highly featured face with interesting colour and some crystal-like holds.

Located on one of the swamp-facing sides of the Malaria boulder. Just to the left of West Nile Direct, and around the corner from Beautiful Odyssey. The ground can get a bit wet so watch your feet. Nice view of the swamp from the top on a warm, fall day.
pad/spotter if you prefer

Start on the far backside of the Chief boulder in a low cave. You can start on the lowest sloping crimp (full value) or the slightly higher rail (original start). Work your way up and out the cave using a big left hand lock off to an ok crimp, deadpoint to a poor half pad sloping right hand crimp that looks unusable then to the lip and awkward mantle.

* note - its hard to avoid dabbing on this

SDS matched on the obvious ledge at the lip. Move up over the right of the bulge using sloping holds at the lip. Mantel tenuously over the bulge and top out on a lichen covered slab.  
  
 The mantel and top out can seem unlikely, especially with the lichen, but the needed holds are all there and clean.  
  
 Essentially this problem is the right exit for West Nile Direct, eliminating the first difficult move to get established on the ledge.

Located near the swamp on the Malaria Boulder. Start on the obvious ledge in the West Nile line and head right.
pad for the slightly uneven, rocky landing
Bouldering area below the main cliffs. Some good problems are there and new ones are yet to be had for sure.
